intro: Pedicularis incurva, commonly known as the bent-lip lousewort, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant is characterized by its spurred flowers, which are typically pink or purple in color, and its ability to grow in nutrient-poor soils. Its leaves are usually opposite and have a lanceolate shape, while its stems are often hairy. Pedicularis incurva is often found in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions.
